explanation:
You must inspect the definitions/declarations of these symbols to decide whether the target function uses any compiler language extensions (MISRA rule under analysis). Reasons: 
- lfs_min: commonly a macro; macros frequently use compiler extensions (e.g. typeof, statement-expressions, GCC-only inline tricks). Check its definition for any extensions. 
- lfs_bd_read: check its prototype/definition to see if it is implemented with compiler-specific extensions (inline asm, attributes, statement-expressions, nonstandard calling conventions, GCC __attribute__ or builtin types). Also check its parameter types to ensure the call in lfs_bd_crc (passing &dat) is standard. 
- lfs_crc: inspect prototype/definition for use of extensions (attributes, builtins, nonstandard types). 
- lfs_t, lfs_cache_t, lfs_size_t, lfs_block_t, lfs_off_t: these typedefs determine whether nonstandard integer types or compiler-specific attributes (packed, aligned, __int128, __attribute__ annotations) are used. Signedness/underlying types also matter for correctness of conversions, and extensions could be hidden here. 
- uint32_t, uint8_t: verify they are standard stdint types (or typedefs) and not implemented via compiler extensions or nonstandard-width types. 
In short: inspect the exact macro/function/type definitions to ensure none use compiler-specific language extensions (typeof, ({ ... }), __attribute__, asm, nonstandard integer kinds, etc.).
